hero.title: Home Customization Experiences on Two Fronts: User Personalization and Designer Curation
hero.subtitle: I showcase several designs that cover all aspects of home customization on the user side and the internal product side.

blocks.text: I led design for major Toll Brothers home customization modules, both internal and external. The three projects I selected showcase elegant UI built on problem solving.

blocks.subtitle: Problems & Goal
blocks.text: For Toll Brothers, “choice” is core to its luxury identity. Users can customize structural options (i.e., fireplaces, room layouts, etc.). However, the old home customization module has major flaws.

items.text: Many options have complex dependencies (e.g., selecting Option A disables Option B), but the UI fails to communicate it.
Users have to rely on trial-and-error and dense tooltips, resulting in a frustrating experience.
It’s built on desktop-first principles, lacks features, and has wonky controls.

blocks.text: The main goal for a redesign will be to scope out all the possible logic dependencies and create a framework that can be systematically visualized.

blocks.subtitle: Research
blocks.text: I researched 80 home designs that offer DYOH and indexed the relationship logic between options. I analyzed the underlying logic and established a proper framework. I reached out to the Architecture team to confirm this framework.

items: Independent - Options that can be toggled independently of any other options.
Child - Options that can be toggled on if another independent option is toggled on.
Conflict Group - 2+ groups of options where only one option can be selected. Sometimes, there are option bundles of 2+ options that are independent of options in the bundle.

blocks.subtitle: Design
blocks.text: In order to redesign the experience around mobile-first principles, I picked the popular bottom sheet pattern that can dynamically alter size based on current focus. I then redesigned the list and demonstrated to stakeholders the framework for categorizing and visualizing dependencies. My manager and an Architecture Product Manager approved of the framework and the overall redesign.

On the internal product side, the product team would curate features for designer-appointed collections using PDFs. As the company pivoted to more pre-selected builds and quick move-in homes, the product team needed an internal tool to construct collections of products at scale. I partnered with a senior developer, and designed the MVP wireframes from scratch. For a desktop-only tool, these were the basic requirements:

items: Add new features to the system.

figures.caption: Collection Builder main page showing collection cards with mosaic feature thumbnail. Cards are categorized by publish states.

A single collection showing added features categorized by location. A general Select Feature button is in the top-right corner, and each location has a smaller location-specific Select Feature button.
Select Features modal shows selected and recommended features. The gray indicator on the top right corner visually indicates selection state and enables location change.
Upload Feature screen lives as a tab on the Select Features modal. It has a suggestive guardrail against duplicate feature uploads.

blocks.text: During the build process, my developer partner and I fleshed out some additional key requirements that were management-focused such as multi-upload, duplicate prevention, and publish states. The demo of this project received internal approval and was added to the backlog.

I revisited the Design Your Own Home module to add a mobile-optimized furniture planner function. The old design has a furniture planner available only on desktop. To elegantly add a furniture planner to mobile, I reduced its prominence, added a variant-selection state, and streamlined out resizing features that do not apply to furniture with preset sizes.

figures.caption: The furniture planner button is placed at the bottom right corner
Users can select from a horizontal carousel of furniture categories.
User can place a default piece and then move, rotate, delete, or change variant.
User can swap variants of the furniture in a dedicated variant-swap state.
